items.title: Driverless racecar sets a new autonomous speed record
items.author: Andrew J. Hawkins
items.summary:
- A Maserati MC20 Coupe achieved a new land speed record for autonomous vehicles by reaching 197.7 mph (318 km/h).
- The record was set at the Kennedy Space Center during an automotive event.
- The autonomous driving software was developed by Politecnico di Milano in collaboration with the Indy Autonomous Challenge.
- This record surpasses the previous record of 192.2 mph set by an IAC AV-21 race car in April 2022.
- The goal of the event includes stress-testing algorithms to improve safety for autonomous road vehicles.
- The Maserati MC20 features a twin-turbocharged 3.0-liter V-6 engine producing 621 horsepower and retails for at least $239,000.

items.title: Hulu prematurely ended its Oscars stream right before the final awards
items.author: Chris Welch
items.summary:
- Hulu cut off its live feed before the Best Actress and Best Picture winners were announced during the Oscars.
- Viewers received a message stating "the live event has now ended," prompting complaints on social media.
- The premature end likely resulted from an incorrectly set broadcast end time of 10:32 PM, coinciding with the planned conclusion of the event.
- Earlier, Hulu acknowledged login issues for some users which were resolved shortly before 9 PM ET.
- Unlike Hulu viewers, cable viewers and those using TV antennas did not face this streaming issue as they received the uninterrupted broadcast.

items.title: Infinix’s new concepts use solar power to charge your phone
items.author: Allison Johnson
items.summary:
- Infinix reveals a phone with an integrated solar panel and a solar charging case at MWC.
- The technology, named SolarEnergy-Reserving, uses perovskite solar cells, allowing for efficient charging up to 2W.
- The solar case charges the phone while it's not in use and can be swapped for a regular case.
- Infinix also showcased a second-gen color-changing E Ink phone powered by AI for customization.
- The demo units were functional, highlighting potential future applications of solar technology in smartphones.

items.title: Instagram’s Threads: all the updates on the new Twitter competitor
items.author: Verge Staff
items.summary:
- Instagram launched its Twitter competitor, Threads, on July 6, 2023.
- Threads allows users to share custom feeds, with options to pin favorite topics or accounts.
- The platform is testing ads, with initial ads appearing in user feeds in the US and Japan.
- Users can now schedule posts up to 75 days in advance, improving content planning.
- A new feature lets users reshare media without quoting the original post, crediting the creator instead.
- Threads is also asking users for feedback on its content moderation policies, signaling a potential shift in their approach.

items.title: Lenovo’s new concept laptop can be charged by the sun
items.author: Andrew Liszewski
items.summary:
- Lenovo announced the Yoga Solar PC, a concept laptop with a solar panel integrated into its lid at Mobile World Congress.
- The solar panel can convert sunlight into power at over 24% efficiency, providing enough energy for an hour of video playback after 20 minutes of direct sunlight.
- The device features Intel Lunar Lake, 32GB of RAM, and a 14-inch OLED display, weighing around 2.29 pounds and measuring 15 mm thick.
- Lenovo has not confirmed production plans yet, similar to the ThinkBook Plus Gen 6 which will become available in June 2025 for $3,499.
- An external solar power kit concept was also revealed, designed to charge devices via USB-C or a power bank.

items.title: Lenovo’s ThinkPad X13 gets even lighter
items.author: Umar Shakir
items.summary:
- Lenovo announces the new ThinkPad X13 Gen 6 at Mobile World Congress, weighing 2.05 pounds, lighter than the Gen 5 (2.25 pounds).
- The X13 features AMD Ryzen AI Pro 300 series processors and Intel options, up to 16GB LPDDR5 RAM, 2TB SSD, and replaceable battery options (41Wh or 54.7Wh).
- Availability in North America starts June 2025, with a starting price of $1,139.
- The ThinkPad T14s is reintroduced as a 2-in-1 with 14-inch touchscreen, up to Intel Core Ultra 7, and available for $1,719.
- Lenovo also unveils a new ThinkBook 16p desktop replacement and plans for the launch of ThinkPad T14 and T16 with pricing starting from $1,359 in May 2025.

items.title: Lenovo’s concept laptop add-ons include multiple monitors and an emoji friend
items.author: Antonio G. Di Benedetto
items.summary:
- Lenovo showcased modular accessories for its ThinkBook 16P Gen 6 at [Mobile World Congress](https://www.theverge.com/news/622379/lenovo-magic-bay-thinkbook-16p-modular-display-tiko-pro-emoji-concepts).
- **Magic Bay 2nd Display Concept**: An 8-inch vertical screen with a 1920 x 1200 resolution and 60Hz refresh rate for feeds and communication apps.
- **Magic Bay Dual Screen Concept**: Dual 13.3-inch displays with 2880 x 1920 resolution and 120Hz refresh rate aimed for a triple-monitor setup.
- **Magic Bay “codename Tiko” Concept**: A small round display serving as an emoji-based AI companion.
- **Magic Bay “codename Tiko Pro” Concept**: A slim horizontal display for widgets and AI integration.
- The Tiko concepts promote lighthearted interactions while also providing practical functionalities for productivity.

items.title: Lenovo’s ThinkBook Flip puts an extra-tall folding display on a laptop
items.author: Antonio G. Di Benedetto
items.summary:
- Lenovo announced the ThinkBook "codename Flip" AI PC Concept at Mobile World Congress.
- The laptop features a flexible display allowing multiple configurations: clamshell mode, tablet mode, and a vertical 18.1-inch screen.
- It uses the same OLED panel as the ThinkBook Plus Gen 6, set to fold behind the main screen.
- The Flip has an extra 0.4 inches of screen real estate compared to the Gen 6 due to its design.
- Users can mirror or extend their display using the rear-facing portion of the screen when in clamshell mode.
- It features a unique Smart ForcePad trackpad with LED-lit shortcuts and media controls.
- Estimated specs include Intel Ultra 7 processor, 32GB of LPDDR5X RAM, PCIe SSD, and Thunderbolt 4 ports.
- The Flip is still in the concept phase, but its design borrows components suggesting it may come to market.

items.title: Trump names Bitcoin and others as part of coming ‘Crypto Strategic Reserve’
items.author: Wes Davis
items.summary:
- President Trump announced cryptocurrencies, including Bitcoin and Ether, will be part of a Crypto Strategic Reserve created by an executive order signed in January.
- The reserve will also include XRP, Solana, and Cardano.
- Trump's order directed the Presidential Working Group to advance on the Crypto Strategic Reserve.
- Under Trump's administration, the SEC has softened its approach towards cryptocurrencies, dropping multiple investigations and lawsuits.
- Ripple’s XRP, previously involved in a SEC lawsuit, was mentioned by Trump, with an ongoing appeal related to its classification as a security.

items.title: FAA Staff Ordered to Secure Funding for Musk's Starlink Deal
items.author: Wes Davis
items.summary:
- FAA officials instructed staff to find tens of millions of dollars for a Starlink deal aimed at upgrading air traffic control communications.
- The deal could potentially disrupt Verizon's existing $2.4 billion government contract for the same services.
- Discussions surrounding this deal have reportedly been informal and verbal, which has raised concerns regarding transparency and the lack of a formal paper trail.
- House Representatives expressed concerns that the deal represents a conflict of interest due to Elon Musk's government affiliations.
- Musk claimed that Verizon’s system was failing but later corrected his statements about its current operational status.

items.title: Siri’s real AI upgrade could still be years away
items.author: Wes Davis
items.summary:
* Apple’s AI upgrade for Siri may not arrive until iOS 20 in 2027, according to Bloomberg’s Mark Gurman.
* The upcoming Siri update in iOS 18.5 will be a separate model from the existing Siri, which is not performing optimally.
* The new architecture aims to improve Siri by combining simple requests and advanced AI capabilities, but is running behind schedule and won’t be presented at WWDC in June.
* Apple’s AI department is facing challenges such as limitations in model performance and difficulty in obtaining necessary hardware for AI training.
* There are reports of ineffective leadership within the department and talent loss to competitors, hindering progress.

items.title: HMD’s new earbuds can top off your phone’s battery
items.author: Allison Johnson
items.summary:
- HMD announced new wireless earbuds called Amped Buds with a charging case that can boost phone batteries using Qi2 reverse wireless charging.
- The earbuds offer active noise cancellation, IP54 splash resistance, and can provide over 95 hours of music playback time when charged fully through the case.
- Priced at €199 (about $206), they will launch in April 2025, although US availability is yet to be confirmed.

items.title: Xiaomi 15 Ultra review: ugly phone, beautiful camera
items.author: Dominic Preston
items.summary:
- Xiaomi 15 Ultra features a new 200-megapixel periscope lens alongside unchanged cameras from the 14 Ultra.
- Despite stellar camera performance, the phone's design is criticized as unattractive, with a dominant asymmetrical camera module.
- The device offers flagship specs including Snapdragon 8 Elite chipset, 16GB RAM, 1TB storage, and 120Hz LTPO OLED display.
- Price set at approximately $1,600 (around ¥1,299 / €1,499).
- Battery life is strong with a 5,410mAh capacity and supports 90W wired and 80W wireless charging.
- The camera excels in low light and provides impressive shots up to 30x zoom, but extreme zoom at 120x requires sharpening adjustments.
- Downsides include preinstalled Xiaomi apps and limited customizability in the HyperOS interface.

items.title: Xiaomi brings its 15 and 15 Ultra flagships to Europe — but the US misses out
items.author: Dominic Preston
items.summary:
- Xiaomi launches the Xiaomi 15 and 15 Ultra smartphones in Europe, following their reveal in China.
- Prices start at £1,299 / €1,499 for the Ultra model and £899 / €999 for the base model.
- Both phones are powered by Snapdragon 8 Elite and offer fast charging and IP68 ratings.
- The Ultra features a unique 200-megapixel periscope lens and a Photography Kit accessory for £179.
- Accompanying the phones are the Xiaomi Pad 7 and Pad 7 Pro tablets with 3.2K displays, starting at £369.
- Xiaomi also released Buds 5 Pro, a Smart Band 9 Pro, and Watch S4 wearable tech.

items.title: Xiaomi Buds 5 Pro are the first to deliver on Qualcomm’s promise of Wi-Fi earbuds
items.author: Dominic Preston
items.summary:
- Xiaomi launched its Buds 5 Pro in Europe, using Qualcomm’s S7 Pro chip for Wi-Fi audio streaming, alongside Bluetooth.
- They support 96kHz/24bit lossless audio with a bandwidth of up to 4.2Mbps, superior to Bluetooth.
- The earbuds' battery life is 10 hours (40 with the case), better than the Bluetooth-only model.
- Priced at £189.99 (around $240) for the Wi-Fi version and £159.99 (around $200) for the Bluetooth version, available in different colors.

items.title: Our favorite speakers, headphones, and other music gear
items.author: David Pierce
items.summary:
- This week’s edition of Installer highlights favorite music gear recommended by readers.
- Popular choices include Sonos speakers, Edifier products, HomePods, KEF LSX, and various soundbars.
- Headphones mentioned frequently are the Sony MDR-7506, Sennheiser HD 600, Sony WF-C510, and Bowers & Wilkins PX7 S2E.
- WiiM products are popular for receivers and amps, while Audio Technica is preferred for turntables.
- Viewers are showing a strong preference for streaming audio through Chromecast Audio. 
- The community is encouraged to share their tech setups and tool recommendations.

items.title: Samsung reveals Galaxy A56 with more AI and a modest spec bump
items.author: Emma Roth
items.summary:
- Samsung has announced new budget-friendly phones including the Galaxy A56, A36, and A26, featuring enhanced AI capabilities.
- New AI features include Best Face for facial expression swaps, improved object removal, and filters, as well as the Circle to Search tool.
- The A56 has a 6.7-inch full HD+ display, upgraded Exynos 1580 chip, and supports 45W charging, with a starting price of $499.
- The A36 launches on March 26 for $399 and the A26 on March 28 for $299, with UK prices set at £499, £399, and £299, respectively.

items.title: From ChatGPT to Gemini: how AI is rewriting the internet
items.author: Verge Staff
items.summary:
- AI in workplaces raises concerns, with 52% of workers worried about its impact on jobs.
- Google and OpenAI are in a competitive race to reshape the internet landscape.
- Google's AI, now called Gemini, is a key player in evolving AI capabilities.

items.title: Ikea registered a Matter-over-Thread temperature sensor with the FCC
items.author: Wes Davis
items.summary:
- Ikea has registered its first Thread device, the "Timmerflotte," a Matter-supporting temperature and humidity sensor, with the FCC.
- The device is powered by two AAA batteries and includes a QR code for Matter setup.
- The Timmerflotte only utilizes the Thread protocol, differing from Ikea's typical use of Zigbee or Wi-Fi. 
- Ikea's Dirigera hub lacks Thread border router capability and can only act as a Matter bridge, not a controller.
- The listing of the Timmerflotte suggests that Ikea may enable Thread radios and Matter controller functionality on the Dirigera, potentially allowing it to act as a standalone smart home hub.

items.title: What can a 100-pixel video teach us about storytelling around the world?
items.author: Kristen Radtke
items.summary:
- CAMP, a Mumbai-based studio, explores storytelling through surveillance and digital archives since 2007.
- Their exhibit at the Museum of Modern Art includes three video projects highlighting sailors' journeys in the Indian Ocean using cellphone footage.
- Founders Shaina Anand and Ashok Sukumaran discuss the archival and participatory nature of their work, emphasizing the importance of preserving low-resolution footage as a storytelling medium.

items.title: All the news about Nvidia’s RTX 50-series GPUs
items.author: Verge Staff
items.summary:
- Nvidia announces the launch of the RTX 5070 Ti, promising performance improvements over last-gen models.
- Some users have reported black screen issues with RTX 50-series GPUs; Nvidia has confirmed a driver update to address this.
- Nvidia acknowledges a manufacturing defect affecting RTX 5090, 5090D, and 5070 Ti cards, resulting in missing render units.
- Customers with affected GPUs can contact board manufacturers for replacements.
- The company also confirms that early production of the RTX 5080 is impacted by the same issue.

items.title: Federal Employees Required to List Weekly Accomplishments
items.author: Wes Davis
items.summary:
- Federal employees received emails asking for a list of weekly accomplishments by 11:59 PM ET every Monday.
- Employees working on classified tasks were told to state that all activities are sensitive.
- Agencies affected include the FBI and Departments of Defense, Justice, Labor, and Agriculture.
- There is uncertainty about consequences for non-compliance with the emails.
- Related context includes a previous email from Elon Musk claiming non-responses would be treated as resignations.
- A federal judge ruled the OPM cannot fire employees from other agencies following mass firings controversy.
- Senator Alex Padilla criticized the emails as wasting resources and potentially misleading employees.

items.title: Amazon’s latest Fire TV Stick 4K Max is more than 30 percent off right now
items.author: Sheena Vasani
items.summary:
- The Fire TV Stick 4K Max is discounted to $39.99, $20 off its regular price.
- It features Wi-Fi 6E, double the storage (16GB), and an upgraded processor for faster performance.
- The device includes a new idle display that shows weather, reminders, and artwork, along with Alexa integration for commands.

items.title: How to find images in Google Photos
items.author: David Nield
items.summary:
- Google Photos automatically backs up photos and videos seamlessly to the cloud.
- To find specific images, users can utilize various search methods: by person, location, date range, and subject.
- The app recognizes individuals and pets, and allows users to add names if faces are not automatically recognized.
- Search by location uses Google Maps data, enabling searches for specific places.
- Users can search images based on date using specific formats in the search bar.
- AI advancements allow for subject searches (e.g., 'beach,' 'food'), though it works best with one search term at a time.

items.title: Go Read This: The Verge’s favorite reads from all over the web
items.author: Verge Staff
items.summary:
- An ongoing collection of notable articles and topics recommended by The Verge.
- Covers various genres including longform journalism, technology, news analysis, and literary recommendations.
- Encourages readers to explore individual posts and join in discussions about the readings.

items.title: One of my favorite pop albums is a video game — and now it’s on the PS5
items.author: Andrew Webster
items.summary: - The game Sayonara Wild Hearts blends rhythm, racing, and action elements, featuring a unique pop album structure. - Recently launched on PS5 with a free upgrade for PS4 owners, enhancing performance and adding an endless mode called remix arcade. - Players control a heartbroken woman restoring harmony in an alternate realm through 23 short levels filled with various gameplay styles and a captivating pop soundtrack.

items.title: Asus ROG Flow Z13 (2025) review: hold up, integrated graphics are good now?
items.author: Antonio G. Di Benedetto
items.summary:
- The Asus ROG Flow Z13 is a 13-inch tablet with a detachable keyboard and AMD Strix Halo processor.
- Remarkably good gaming performance for integrated graphics, making it comparable to traditional gaming hardware.
- Starting price is $2,100; review unit priced at $2,299 with enhanced specs.
- Features a 13.4-inch, 180Hz IPS touchscreen display with pen support.
- Long battery life of up to 10 hours in non-gaming tasks.
- The design is portable and versatile, effectively replacing a desktop, laptop, and handheld for some gamers.
- Performance is capable of running modern games at respectable frame rates on high settings.

items.title: Amazon Launches Alexa Plus, a Significant Upgrade to Its Voice Assistant
items.author: Jennifer Pattison Tuohy
items.summary:
- Amazon introduced **Alexa Plus**, a generative AI-powered upgrade to its voice assistant, focusing on software improvements rather than new hardware.
- The new Alexa is designed to be **conversational, proactive**, and capable of tasks like booking restaurants, planning itineraries, and integrating with smart devices more seamlessly.
- Alexa Plus will be available for **$19.99 a month** and will launch in late March 2025, with initial access limited to users with specific Echo devices.

items.title: Mozilla Revises Firefox Terms to Clarify User Data Handling
items.author: Jay Peters
items.summary:
- Mozilla is updating its Firefox Terms of Use after criticism regarding perceived broad ownership of user data.
- Changes aim to clarify the limited scope of data usage by Mozilla, reflecting community concerns.
- A key statement regarding user data licensing has been revised for better clarity, emphasizing that Mozilla does not own user content.
- Mozilla acknowledges the need for more precise language related to data sharing practices and the evolving legal definitions of data sale.
- The update follows a previous announcement aimed at addressing transparency about data handling in Firefox.

items.title: Google’s co-founder tells AI staff to stop ‘building nanny products’
items.author: Alex Heath
items.summary:
[Google co-founder Sergey Brin emphasizes the urgency in AI development at DeepMind.]
[He advocates for longer work hours and prioritizing simple, efficient solutions.]
[Brin insists on trusting users and stopping the creation of overly protective AI products.]

items.title: Zapier says someone broke into its code repositories and may have accessed customer data
items.author: Jay Peters
items.summary:
- An unauthorized user accessed Zapier's code repositories, potentially gaining customer information.
- The issue was due to a two-factor authentication (2FA) misconfiguration on an employee's account.
- Zapier secured access to the repositories upon discovering the breach and stated it did not affect their main systems.

items.title: The Verge looks back on Skype
items.author: Verge Staff
items.summary:
- Skype was a primary communication tool before the rise of Zoom and Google Meet.
- Originally released in 2003 and acquired by Microsoft in 2011, it offered internet phone and video calls.
- Microsoft announced Skype's shutdown on May 5, 2025, encouraging users to transition to Teams.
- Many users shared personal stories about how Skype connected them during significant life moments.
- Skype's decline is attributed to neglect after Microsoft's acquisition, leading to its eventual obscurity in favor of newer platforms.

items.title: The UK will neither confirm nor deny that it’s killing encryption
items.author: Jess Weatherbed
items.summary:
- The UK government has demanded Apple create a backdoor to iCloud to access encrypted data.
- Apple's Advanced Data Protection feature has been withdrawn from UK customers, impacting global data security efforts.
- The Investigatory Powers Act allows the UK to legally require companies to provide access to user data, raising privacy concerns on a global scale.
- Other encryption providers like Meta and Signal have remained silent on the UK's demands, despite the potential implications for their services.
- Privacy rights groups and international governments, including the US, are concerned about the UK's approach to encryption and surveillance.

items.title: The armless PP-1 turntable is made from a solid block of aluminum
items.author: Andrew Liszewski
items.summary:
- A minimalist turntable named PP-1 has been announced by Paris-based creative studio Waiting For Ideas.
- The turntable features only a play button and a volume knob and lacks a visible tonearm.
- Made from a solid block of anodized aluminum, it has a price tag of €5,800 (approximately $6,012) and requires about 12 weeks to produce.
- Unlike some modern turntables, the PP-1 uses traditional hardware with an inverted cartridge hidden behind a door system when not in use.
- It does not have a speed control dial; instead, it automatically adjusts playback speed for optimal performance.
- Users must remember to place records upside down to play them correctly.
- Power is supplied via a single USB-C port, and it has one 3.5mm audio jack for connecting to speakers.
- Matching passive speakers are available for preorder at €3,200 ($3,320), but an additional amplifier is required.

items.title: Tesla Superchargers coming to dozens of Steak ‘n Shake locations
items.author: Andrew J. Hawkins
items.summary:
- Tesla plans to install Supercharger stations at Steak ‘n Shake locations across the U.S.
- An agreement has been signed for over six initial sites, with the potential for up to 100 locations.
- The partnership was revealed through interactions on social media, including comments from Elon Musk.
- Tesla has previously partnered with other restaurant chains for charging station installations.
- Federal funding for new charging locations may be impacted after the Trump administration halted a $5 billion program.

items.title: The Verge hires Tina Nguyen as senior reporter to cover the Trump administration
items.author: Verge Press Room
items.summary:
- Tina Nguyen has joined The Verge as a senior reporter.
- She will cover the Trump administration, Elon Musk’s actions regarding the government, and the tech industry's ties to the MAGA movement.
- Nguyen was previously at Puck as a national correspondent and has reported for Politico and Vanity Fair.
- She authored "The MAGA Diaries: Life Among the Fanatics, Extremists, and True Believers that Created the Modern Right."
- Her hiring is part of The Verge's expansion plans for 2025, following a successful subscription launch in December.
- Other recent hires include Marina Galperina, Todd Haselton, and Dominic Preston for various senior roles.

items.title: Cold Wallet’s director wanted to make a revenge thriller for the crypto era
items.author: Charles Pulliam-Moore
items.summary:
- *Cold Wallet* is a darkly comedic home invasion thriller directed by Cutter Hodierne, revolving around retail investors making risky choices in the crypto market.
- The film's protagonist, Billy, bets everything on a new cryptocurrency named Tulip, reflecting the desperation and enthusiasm found in the crypto community.
- Inspired by real events like the Quadriga debacle, the story illustrates the dangers of investing in crypto and critiques capitalism's impact on individuals.

items.title: Roblox: all the news about the popular social and gaming platform
items.author: Verge Staff
items.summary:
- Roblox introduces a new AI chatbot to assist in building virtual worlds.
- The platform is integrating generative AI tools for easier game design, akin to 'Westworld' capabilities.
- A new child safety initiative named ROOST has been established by Roblox, Discord, OpenAI, and Google to improve online safety.
- Unlicensed Robux casinos have shut down following investigations into online gambling targeting children.
- Roblox has launched a Top 100 music chart highlighting popular songs within the platform.
- Changes aimed at child safety include new rules limiting communication for users under 13.
- Roblox will block children from accessing certain experiences with interactive features to enhance safety.
- The platform is facing scrutiny regarding inflated user numbers as per Hindenburg Research allegations.

items.title: Trump’s Impact on the Tech Industry During His First 100 Days
items.author: Verge Staff
items.summary:
- The Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE) plans to lay off most employees at the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB).
- The CFPB has returned $17.5 billion to consumers over 12 years and is currently facing layoffs amid legal challenges.
- Recent reports highlight significant layoffs affecting the CFPB's technology team, putting the agency's future at risk.
- Elon Musk’s imposition of productivity emails has generated confusion among federal employees, with threats of resignation for non-compliance.
- Controversies include Ted Cruz's labeling of a mint research project as 'woke' and potential misinformation in media about government contracts.

items.title: DOGE plans to lay off the majority of CFPB workers, employees claim
items.author: Lauren Feiner
items.summary:
- The Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE) intends to fire the majority of employees at the CFPB, according to sworn declarations from current and former staff.
- Employees reported that a rapid firing process is being executed, bypassing usual procedures as part of a larger dismantling of the CFPB.
- A temporary court order has halted further layoffs, but a significant number of employees have already been affected.
- Concerns were raised about the long-term impacts on consumer protection and the security of CFPB data due to the abrupt contract terminations.

items.title: Steam’s Next Fest is full of weird-ass, cool-ass games
items.author: Ash Parrish
items.summary:
- Steam Next Fest is ongoing until March 3rd, featuring numerous indie game demos.
- Key demos highlighted include:
  - **The Talos Principle: Reawakened**: A remaster adding new story content and puzzle editor.
  - **Bundle of Joy**: A narrative game about new parenthood during the pandemic with a focus on empathy.
  - **Creepy Redneck Dinosaur Mansion 3**: A comedic metroidvania with match-3 mechanics, featuring an amusing storyline.
  - **Promise Mascot Agency**: A bizarre game where a disgraced yakuza manages a mascot business to help revive a town.
- The event showcases unique game concepts that may defy traditional explanations but foster creativity among developers.

items.title: Mozilla says its new Firefox terms don’t give it ownership of your data
items.author: Jay Peters
items.summary:
- Mozilla introduced new Terms of Use for Firefox that faced criticism for suggesting ownership over user data.
- Users raised concerns over the phrase granting Mozilla a nonexclusive, royalty-free license to use user-uploaded information.
- Mozilla clarified that the terms are necessary for basic functionality, stating it does not claim ownership over user data beyond what is specified in their Privacy Notice.
- The language choices were explained: 'nonexclusive' indicates users retain rights, 'royalty-free' reflects the free nature of Firefox, and 'worldwide' signifies global availability.
- Mozilla emphasized that the changes aren't related to using data for AI or selling it to advertisers, ensuring data usage is within the Privacy Notice guidelines.

items.title: EVgo prohibits fast-charging extension cables and breakaway adapters
items.author: Umar Shakir
items.summary:
- EVgo revised its terms of service on March 8th to ban the use of DC extension cables and breakaway adapters at its stations.
- The new policy prohibits any unauthorized adapters, continuing to allow only automaker-manufactured chargers.
- The ban impacts EV accessory makers like A2Z EV, which recently launched a DC extension cord for fast-charging stations.

items.title: All the news about EV charging in the US
items.author: Verge Staff
items.summary:
- The electric vehicle (EV) charging landscape in North America resembles the smartphone charging wars, focusing on hardware compatibility.
- Tesla is opening its connector as the North American Charging Standard (NACS), countering the more widespread Combined Charging System (CCS).
- NACS is being standardized by SAE International, with major automakers like Ford, GM, and Toyota signing on to adopt it.
- A federal investment of $7.5 billion aims to improve EV charging infrastructure reliability across the U.S.
- Kia EVs will gain access to Tesla Superchargers in March 2025, with initial delays in the rollout.
- Mercedes-Benz vehicles will also gain access to Tesla's Supercharging network, starting in February 2025.

items.title: Apple’s AirTags are on sale for their best price to date
items.author: Quentyn Kennemer
items.summary:
- Apple AirTags four-pack is on sale for $64.49, providing a savings of about $35.
- Individual AirTags are available for $22.99 (about $6 off).
- AirTags utilize the ultra wideband technology in newer iPhones for precision tracking and connect to the Find My network for locating out of range.

items.title: The Best Nintendo Switch Controllers to Buy Right Now
items.author: Quentyn Kennemer
items.summary:
- The default Joy-Cons are less comfortable for long sessions, especially for larger hands.
- Recommended controllers cater to different play styles, including TV and handheld modes.
- Top choices include the **Nintendo Switch Pro Controller** for TV mode, offering HD rumble and gyro motion support, and the **Hori Split Pad Pro** for handheld mode, which excels in ergonomics.
- **GuliKit KingKong 3 Pro** and **KingKong 3 Max** are highlighted as great Xbox-style controllers with extensive customization options.
- Third-party controllers may lack some features, like HD rumble and NFC support for Amiibo.
- Pricing varies, with some controllers generally being on the pricier side but considered worthwhile for comfort and usability.

items.title: The best indie games we’re playing right now
items.author: Verge Staff
items.summary:
- Highlights a variety of indie games that are currently popular.
- Emphasizes the creativity and uniqueness of indie games compared to mainstream titles.
- List includes games like *Die in the Dungeon*, *While Waiting*, and *Spirit Swap* that offer innovative gameplay mechanics and narratives.
- The article will be updated frequently with new recommendations.

items.title: MWC 2025: all the phones, gadgets, and commentary from Barcelona
items.author: Verge Staff
items.summary:
- Mobile World Congress 2025 will be held in Barcelona from March 3rd to March 6th, with announcements starting March 2nd.
- Companies like Xiaomi, HMD, and Honor are expected to unveil new devices, including Xiaomi's flagship 15 series.
- The show will focus on mobile technology and AI, even as its prominence has declined compared to past events.

items.title: Intel pushes Ohio chip factory opening to 2030
items.author: Emma Roth
items.summary:
- Intel is delaying the opening of its $28 billion Ohio chip plants to between 2030 and 2031, pushed back from the initial plan of 2025.
- The second fabrication plant is not expected to open until 2032.
- Intel cites financial responsibility and customer demand as reasons for the delay, amidst ongoing financial struggles including mass layoffs and a major CEO change.

items.title: What to expect at MWC 2025
items.author: Dominic Preston
items.summary:
- Mobile World Congress (MWC) 2025 runs from March 3rd to March 6th, with announcements starting March 2nd.
- Xiaomi will launch its 15 series, including the regular 15 and 15 Ultra, focusing on photography with a 200MP lens.
- Nothing will unveil its 3A series on March 4th, featuring its first triple camera with optical zoom.
- Samsung may tease the Galaxy S25 Edge but no major announcements are expected.
- HMD has a press conference planned for March 2nd, possibly related to a new Nokia-branded device.
- Lenovo is anticipated to reveal various laptops including the foldable ThinkBook Flip.
- Honor will present its new corporate vision, the “Alpha Plan,” on March 2nd.
- Realme plans to launch its 14 Pro series and tease a new phone with premium features. 
- Tecno and TLC will also make announcements, focusing on camera technology and new phone releases.
